message_1: Suppose a data set has the following values: 10, 15, 12, 13, 20, 25, 18, 14, 22, and 27. Determine if there are any outliers in the data set using the 1.5*IQR rule.
message_2:
First, we need to sort the data set in ascending order: 10, 12, 13, 14, 15, 18, 20, 22, 25, 27.

Next, we find the median (Q2), lower quartile (Q1), and upper quartile (Q3).

The median (Q2) is the average of the two middle values: (15 + 18) / 2 = 16.5.

The lower quartile (Q1) is the median of the lower half of the data: (12 + 13) / 2 = 12.5.

The upper quartile (Q3) is the median of the upper half of the data: (22 + 25) / 2 = 23.5.

Now we can calculate the interquartile range (IQR): IQR = Q3 - Q1 = 23.5 - 12.5 = 11.

Next, we find the lower and upper bounds for outliers using the 1.5*IQR rule:

Lower bound = Q1 - 1.5 * IQR = 12.5 - 1.5 * 11 = -3.5
Upper bound = Q3 + 1.5 * IQR = 23.5 + 1.5 * 11 = 39.5

Now we check if there are any values in the data set that are below the lower bound or above the upper bound:

10, 12, 13, 14, 15, 18, 20, 22, 25, 27

All values are within the range of -3.5 to 39.5, so there are no outliers in the data set using the 1.5*IQR rule.
